row.ClassDescription__c: Abstract class that defines communication endpoints in your IT environment. The BMC_AccessPoint class groups together access-point related classes. An access point represents the ability to use or invoke a service. This characteristic is further defined by BMC_ProtocolEndpoint, the only direct subclass of BMC_AccessPoint. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Therefore, you might use subclasses such as IP addresses, MAC addresses, IPX addresses, and so forth. Instances of the BMC_AccessPoint class are related to a system through a BMC_HostedAccessPoint dependency relationship. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_ServiceAccessPoint.

Class that stores information about accounts in your IT environment that are used to access specific resources, and also represents the credentials used to log on to a system. An instance of this class is usually related to a BMC_Person instance representing the user who owns the account, and is always connected to a CI in the subclass of BMC_System. For example, the Name attribute inherited from BMC_BaseElement can define the user name for the account. An account should not exist without a relationship to a system, but it can exist without a relationship to a person. Also, an account should not be connected to more than one person or role. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that links accounts (such as BMC_Account instances) to a system (for example, a BMC_ApplicationSystem, a BMC_ComputerSystem, or a BMC_AdminDomain instance). An account-system relationship provides uniqueness for the unqualified account name (typically, the user ID) within the scope of the system. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_AccountOnSystem.

Class that represents a function or step in a business process definition. You can use this class to serve as a superclass for other activity types. This class is the superclass for the BMC_BusinessProcess class, which stores activity definitions. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about standalone applications, applications deployed on servers (such as J2EE and SAP), and applications deployed on distributed systems (such as SAP). An application can be hosted by two different types of environments. The application can run on a physical or virtual system, or it can run on an application server or application system. Therefore, when modeling applications, relate an instance of the BMC_Application class to a hosting BMC_ComputerSystem (physical or virtual), BMC_ApplicationServer, or BMC_ApplicationInfrastructure instance. For example, if an application runs directly on top of an application server or application system such as an SAP environment, the application has only one relationship, a dependency on the application infrastructure hosting the application. This dependency is modeled by a BMC_Dependency relationship. When using the relationship, set the Name value to DEPLOYEDAPPLICATION. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_ApplicationSystem class.

Class that stores information about an application or a software system that supports a particular business function and that can be managed as an independent unit. This class cannot be instantiated. To decompose the system into its technical components, relate an instance of this class to its component BMC_SoftwareServer instance using the BMC_Dependency class. For example, a J2EE run-time environment would be represented by BMC_SoftwareServer. BMC_ApplicationSystem also represents the core class of the application system's submodel of the application runtime model. Its role in the system's submodel is to represent the root node of the containment hierarchy of the application elements (at runtime) as services, components, subsystems, and the main entry point to the navigation through and drill-down into the runtime model. It also serves to store run-time overview information (such as response time or system status), and to control the run time of the entire application (for example, start and stop). To capture the deployed, run-time aspects of long-lived applications, use BMC_SoftwareServer, BMC_Application, or BMC_ApplicationInfrastructure. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_ ApplicationSystem.

Relationship class that links components to application systems (such as BMC_ApplicationSystem instances). Use this class to define the components that make up an application system. For example, an Oracle application (BMC_ApplicationSystem) hosts application services, TimeCard and HR personal data, both stored in the BMC_ApplicationService class. The two classes relate to each other through the weak relationship BMC_ApplicationSystemServices, meaning that both the TimeCard and HR personal data services are dependent on the host Oracle application. A system service is a service offered by a computer system to perform a set of functions on demand. A system service is generally associated with a software program that can be started and stopped. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that is the CDM common base class (at the top of the inheritance tree) for configuration item (CI) classes. Attributes of this class are inherited by all CI classes. In addition to attributes such as Name that you populate for all CIs, BMC_BaseElement also contains core attributes such as CompareActionCode, which is populated automatically by the BMC Atrium CMDB, and CreateDate, which is populated automatically by AR System. For relationships, the CDM common base class is BMC_BaseRelationships. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_ManagedElement.

Relationship class that is a common base class (located at the top of the inheritance tree) for the relationship classes in the CDM. Though you are unlikely to create any instances of this class, you can use its form as a single place to query for all relationships. Attributes of this class are inherited by all relationship classes. In addition to attributes (such as Name) that you populate for all relationships, BMC_BaseRelationship also contains core attributes (such as InstanceId, ReconciliationIdentity, and ClassId) that are populated automatically by the BMC Atrium CMDB, and CreateDate, populated automatically by BMC Remedy AR System. Use the Name attribute of BMC_BaseRelationship to further categorize relationships according to the Relationship Normalization Table found in the BMC Atrium CMDB Common Data Model documentation. For configuration item (CI) classes, the CDM common base class is BMC_BaseElement. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that groups a structured sequence of activities that make up a business process or an IT process. A business process is a process performed by some combination of people, computers, and equipment to provide a business service or to deliver a product. An IT process is a business process performed by the IT department, such as the ITSM Change Management or Incident Management processes. This class has BMC_Component relationships to activity and subprocess instances. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about business or technical services. A business service can be provided from one business to another, or from one organization to another within a business (for example, customer support, order processing, and payroll). A technical service can be provided by an IT organization to support business services or IT's own operations (for example, employee provisioning, backup and recovery, and self-service help desk). It can also represent a service offering (captured by a certain type of infrastructure) and the Service Level Targets associated with that service (for example, Web farms or storage). This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about groups of two or more computer systems (clusters) or applications that operate together as a functional whole to increase the performance or resources of the BMC_System component. Use the BMC_Cluster class to classify or update groups of software or hardware to maintain and improve the reliability, serviceability, and availability of your operating-system environment. For example, an accounting department might create a cluster and link it with relationships to specific computer systems to obtain a complete picture of their business environment and assess the performance of computers individually and collectively. To do so, they could use the BMC_Component relationship to connect Computer A, Computer B, and Computer C to a performance measurement CI in the BMC_Cluster class. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_Cluster.

Abstract class that stores information about collections of configuration items (CIs) related to the people and organizational characteristics of your IT environment. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Therefore, you should use subclasses of BMC_Collection (for example, BMC_Role and BMC_Organization) to represent particular groups of CIs in your IT environment. For example, BMC_Role models the roles for granting permissions and representing participants in your business processes and transactions. This class, formerly named BMC_Group in the BMC Atrium CMDB 1.0, corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_Collection.

Class that stores information about communication protocol endpoints (communication points from which data can be sent or received, linking system or computerinterfaces to logical networks),) that are dedicated to TCP (transmission control protocol) or UDP (user datagram protocol). This class is a combination of the DMTF CIM_ TCPProtocolEndpoint and CIM_UDPProtocolEndpoint classes.

Class used to relate "part of" relationships between any two configuration item (CI) classes. For example, it can be used to define the patches that are installed on a software product. It can also be used to define the activities or steps that make up a business process. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Component class.

Class that stores configuration items (CIs) relating to collections of managed system elements. The managed system elements provide computing capabilities and serve as aggregation points to relate one or more of the following elements: file systems, operating systems, processors, and memory (volatile storage, nonvolatile, or storage). The BMC_ComputerSystem class is the primary class that you will use to model the computers in your organization. You can use the attributes in this class to identify the purpose of each computer CI in your organization. For example, the class contains several attributes that represent any network-addressable system, such as a server, a workstation, or a network device (router, switch, hub, load balancer, firewall, and so forth), as well as mainframes, printers, and virtual systems. So CMDB planners might use the PrimaryCapability element to define a vendor-specific switch used in their network, making it easy to import this data from a vendor as an industry-standard item in their CMDB. They could also define computer systems further by placing them in one of its subclasses: BMC_Mainframe, BMC_Printer, or BMC_VirtualSystem. The BMC_ComputerSystem class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_ComputerSystem.

Class used to store a generic and instantiable collection, such as a pool of hosts available for running jobs. This class is defined as a concrete subclass of BMC_Collection and was added rather than changing BMC_Collection from an abstract class to a concrete class. BMC_ConcreteCollection must not be subclassed When extending the common data model. Instead, you should define new functionality in the existing BMC_Collection subclasses or create new subclasses. This class corresponds to the CIM_ConcreteCollection DMTF CIM class.

Class that groups a set of protocol endpoints of the same type that can communicate with each other. It can also group related systems, users, or other base elements. All members of the group must be in the same administrative domain or computer system. The BMC_MemberOfCollection class is used to relate the entities grouped by this class. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_ConnectivityCollection class.

Class that groups endpoints of the same type (for example, Ethernet, fiber channel, or token ring) that can communicate without the assistance of bridging or routing services. Such endpoints are sometimes referred to as members of the same "collision domain." The BMC_InSegment class is used to relate instances of this class to those endpoints, which are instances of BMC_LANEndpoint. In the Name attribute of this class, enter a hash code based on the list of physical addresses that belong to the segment and the name of the LAN instance that the segment belongs to. In the NameFormat attribute, enter the formula that generates the Name value. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_LANConnectivitySegment class.
Class that acts as a container object made up of line items that establish a specific agreement between a provider and a customer.
Relationship class that defines the relationship between the contract and the contract line item.
Class that stores contract line items that establish specific agreements between the provider and the customer.

Class that is used to represent a logical database (a collection of interrelated data organized into one or more schemas and treated as a unit). You should create an instance of this class for each separately manageable database. To represent an installation of a database management system, use the BMC_SoftwareServer class (set its SoftwareServerType attribute to DatabaseServer). Alternately, you can use the BMC_Application class (set its ApplicationType attribute to InfrastructureApplication).To represent database storage areas, use the BMC_DataBaseStorage class. The key to a BMC_DataBase instance in an enterprise environment is its Name attribute. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_CommonDatabase.

Relationship class that represents a generic association used to establish dependent relationships between objects in order to describe the organization of a business process and its dependencies. For example, the class can be used to specify that a business service is dependent on a system. At the business level, the relationship could be due to a distributed business process. At the technical level, the relationship can be interpreted as communication between application systems. ; Typically, BMC_Activity or BMC_BusinessProcess may depend on one or more CIs of any type. For example, BMC_Activity will depend on abstract objects, such as BMC_Role or BMC_WebService. One of the most frequent uses of BMC_Dependency is to indicate that one entity is using another. ; This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_Dependency.

Class that stores all documents related to an IT infrastructure in the CMDB. It categorizes any type of documented information in your IT environment, and includes attributes that specify various properties of the documentation. It also includes an attachment field for storing documentation. This class is included in the Common Data Model because ITIL defines documentation as one of the six elements that compose a CMDB. Therefore, if you have documents that are critical to your configuration and you want to track them as CIs, this class enables you to do so. For example, you can use the BMC_Document class to include a disaster recovery plan in an impact model. As another example, IT or business managers might need planning reports that detail crucial steps involved in establishing change and configuration processes in their enterprise. The BMC_Document class can store these reports, as well as the author's name and the creation date. Additionally, the manager can attach the report using the DocumentAttachment attribute. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class used to relate any configuration item (CI) class to a location for site, inventory, and maintenance purposes. Physical elements can have locations. Other types of CIs, however, might also be related to locations. For example, organizations might exist in one or more locations, or services might be restricted to one location. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_ElementLocation class.
Class that stores information about physical objects, such as disks, disk drives, display screens, keyboards, printers, motherboards, and chips. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that relates an access point to the system on which it resides. The relationship is one-to-many (each system can host many access points) and the access point is weak with respect to the system. If the implementation of the access point is also stored in BMC Atrium CMDB, that implementation must be a device or software feature instance that is part of the same system hosting the access point. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_HostedAccessPoint class.

Class that relates a service and the system on which the service resides. The relationship is one-to-many (a system can host many services) and the service is weak with respect to the system. A service is hosted on the system where logical devices or software features that implement the service are located. The CDM has no classes that represent services hosted across multiple systems. It represents an application system that acts as an aggregation point for services that are each located on a single host. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_HostedService class.

Relationship class that establishes "part of" relationships between a system and the managed system elements of which the system is composed. This class is a subclass of BMC_Component, representing a more specific type of component relationship. Use this class to relate system components, and use BMC_Component to relate other types of components. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
Relationship class that represents a generic association used to establish impact relationships between objects. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
Class that relates an IP endpoint to an IP subnet. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
Class that relates an endpoint to a segment of a local area network (LAN). This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_InSegment class.
Class stores information about communication endpoints dedicated to running IP. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_IPProtocolEndpoint class.

Class that stores information about communication endpoints that, when their related interface device is connected to a LAN, can send and receive dataframes. LAN endpoints include MAC addresses, and Ethernet, token ring, and FDDI interfaces. The BMC_InSegment class is used to relate instances of the BMC_ConnectivitySegment class to instances of BMC_LANEndpoint. To represent individual Large Area Networks (LNs), use the BMC_LANEndpoint class. To relate individual LNs to an instance of BMC_LNsCollection, use the BMC_LNsInCollection class. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_LANEndpoint.
Class that relates sets of protocol endpoints (instances of BMC_ConnectivityCollection) to build logical networks (an instance of BMC_LNsCollection). This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class used to store all of the components in a system that represent abstract system components. Examples of logical enitities might be Payroll Processes or North American Sales. You use these CI types to define accounts, business processes, databases, and so on. Abstract classes cannot hold any instances. Instead, use subclasses such as BMC_Activity and BMC_BusinessService to represent particular types of logical entities in your IT environment, such as Service Model components. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_LogicalElement class.

Class that stores information about system components that can be physically implemented in various ways or that are composed of several physical components. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class used to store information about mainframe computer systems. A mainframe is a very large computer capable of supporting hundreds, or even thousands, of users simultaneously. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Relationship class that represents a set of CIs to establish membership of base managed elements in a collection. A collection is a logical grouping of related entities into an abstract container object. For example, this relationship can be used to link endpoints, systems, or users to an instance of BMC_Collection or its subclasses. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_MemberOfCollection.
Class that stores information about internal storage areas in a computer. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Memory class.

Class that stores information about service offerings that are part of a high-level service. Service offerings are container objects that combine the utility (business or technical service), and the warranty (defined by Service Level Targets) to bring value to customers. For example, a business service offering may have an SLT that requires that IT Support can deliver the service to customers in no more than two hours. This service offering might be named ERP Gold, based on a service called ERP defined in the service catalog. Business customers do not subscribe to services, they subscribe to service offerings.
Relationship class that defines the relationship between the offering and the Service Level Target.

Class that stores information about business organizations including business units. An organization is composed of employees and contractors who are providers or consumers of business services. A business unit can be composed of multiple organizations. This class is a combination of the DMTF CIM_Organization and CIM_OrganizationalEntity classes.

Class that stores information about the people who provide, consume, use, maintain, own, or have some other relationship with the services, systems, and other configuration items (CIs) in your organization. The BMC_Person class contains many attributes that can help you define and classify individuals that perform some role in your organization. For example, the PersonAdditionalDetails attribute enables you to provide additional role, responsibility, or other pertinent information about a person by typing up to 254 characters in a field. You might use the BMC_Person class as an extension of the BMC_Role class. For example, if you have classified certain individuals to perform a specific IT or business process in your IT environment (and defined this role in the BMC_Role class), you can obtain detailed contact information for that person to help streamline communications with other people in the organization. The BMC_Person class is based on, and is an extension of, a combination of the DMTF classes CIM_Person and PRS_Person.
Class used to store information about the position and address of physical elements. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Location class.
Class that stores information about local and network printers. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Printer class.

Class that stores information about communication points from which data can be sent or received. Protocol endpoints link system or computer interfaces to logical networks. The available links are defined by the subclasses of protocol endpoint, communication, IP, and LAN. You can store links that do not fall into any of these subclasses within the BMC_ProtocolEndpoint class. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_ProtocolEndpoint.

Class that stores information about the position or responsibilities that a person or system has in an IT organization, or in any other aspect of IT or business processes. One or more persons, systems, or a combination of both can be assigned to a role, and a person or system can have multiple roles. Using the BMC_Role class, IT and business managers can model roles and responsibilities in their organization, grant permissions to specific groups or individuals, and represent participants in a business process or transaction. A subclass of BMC_Collection (formerly BMC_Group), the BMC_Role class can be an effective way to extend groupings in an organization by classifying the people that perform business-related processes and tasks. For example, account managers may be assigned a role that is very similar to that of a business relationship manager, except that the role might include more commercial aspects because the person will primarily be dealing with external customers. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_Role.

Class that stores information about Service Level Targets (SLTs). SLTs define the warranty of a service and defines the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) used to measure the performance of a service offering.
Relationship class that defines the relationship between the business service and the offering.

Class that represents the association between ManagedElements and applicable setting data. This association also describes whether this is a default or current setting. Each non-null, non-key property of the associated SettingData instance defines a setting value for the associated ManagedElement. The attributes of this class (IsDefault, IsCurrent, IsNext, IsMinimum, IsMaximum, and IsPending) further qualify those setting values. Note: the referenced SettingData instance does not reflect the current preferred state of the referenced ManagedElement unless IsCurrent is set to Is Current. When IsMinimum or IsMaximum attributes are set to the value Is Minimum or Is Maximum, respectively, the referenced SettingData instance reflects the preferred minimum or maximum values, respectively. When IsMinimum and IsMaximum are set to any other value, the referenced SettingData reflects actual preferred values.

Abstract class that defines software elements for a particular platform. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Therefore, you might use subclasses (such as BMC_Patch, BMC_Product, and BMC_SystemSoftware) to represent particular types of software elements in your IT environment. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_SoftwareElement.

Abstract class that defines the systems in your organization. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Instead, use subclasses such as BMC_ApplicationSystem, BMC_Cluster, and BMC_ComputerSystem to represent particular types of systems. A system is a logical element that groups base elements; the group operates as a functional whole, providing the scope for numerous components. Although a system may be viewed as a collection, a collection is simply a container for its members, while a system is a higher-level abstraction built out of its individual components. It is more than the sum of its parts. For example, systems can serve as anchors that hold multiple items together, (such as computer systems, clusters, application systems, and domains). Therefore, when studying or planning the CDM, you should consider using the BMC_System class because of its relationships with many other classes in the model. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_System.

Abstract class that defines elements that compose a system. These elements can consist of hardware or logical system components. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Therefore, you might use subclasses such as BMC_HardwareSystemComponent and BMC_LogicalSystemComponent to represent particular types of system components. For example, you might group a specific processor as an instance of BMC_HardwareSystemComponent, and a software package for that processor as an instance of BMC_LogicalSystemComponent. The BMC_SystemComponent class shares a close association with the BMC_System class. The main relationship between the two is the BMC_HostedSystemComponenents relationship, enabling you to model a complete computer system by linking a PC with all of its components. However, be careful when you use this class to establish relationships. For example, access points that are dependent and hosted on a system are not components of the system. The system is not made up of any parts of access points, which is why you should use the dependency relationship, BMC_HostedAccessPoint, to relate endpoints to systems. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_SystemComponent.

Class that stores information about operating systems and all utility programs that manage computer resources at a low level. Use subclasses of this class to represent specific operating system and BIOS (basic input/output system) software elements in your IT environment. For example, IT administrators can use the BMC_VirtualSystemEnabler subclass (and its BMC_VMWare subclass) to configure virtualization software and hardware in their data center. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that specifies a single transaction initiated by an end user or system. For example, a user selecting a web page from a user interface is a transaction, just as a computer program calling a web service to perform a function in another computer program is also a transaction.

Class that stores information about a collection of users (persons) who consume business services. Typically, the users are external to the organization or they cross organizational boundaries. While BMC_Role and BMC_Organization CIs represent official designations within your business, CIs that you populate within the BMC_UserCommunity class can be more informal. For example, you might group internet users in this class to represent a broad audience. The BMC_UserCommunity class will be deprecated in a future release. You should instead use BMC_Organization or BMC_ConcreteCollection to model users who consume business services. The BMC_UserCommunity class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about devices that interpret a sequence of machine instructions on a computer. To represent a multiprocessor machine, create one instance of the BMC_Processor class for each processor. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Processor class.
Class that stores information about software or firmware that controls the operation of a computer and directs the processing of programs. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_OperatingSystem class

Class that represents a type of BMC_ApplicationSystem CI that provides dedicated server functionality through a running process (or processes) on a computer system. A CI of this type provides a single service to client applications or other systems. For example, database servers, Web servers, DNS servers, and directory servers can be represented by this class. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_SoftwareFeature class.

Class that stores configuration items (CIs) relating to groups of system components, such as software (for example, servers, databases, and applications), operating system (for example, files, processes, and threads), devices (for example, disk drives, controllers, processors, and printers), and physical components (for example, chips and cards).
Class that stores information about devices on which data can be stored, such as hard disks, floppy disks, CD-ROMs, and tapes. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_PhysicalMedia class

Class used to store information about groups of computers and devices that are administered as a unit with common rules and procedures on a Microsoft Windows NT network. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class

Class that stores information about the capabilities and management of disk drives. A disk drive is a machine that reads data from and writes data to a disk. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_DiskDrive class.

Class that stores information about the framework (such as SAP or J2EE) that supports applications in a distributed or composite system. This class represents the platform to model your applications. For example, you would model SAP as an instance of BMC_ApplicationInfrastructure. Once an application is deployed in that platform, it can run on any application server in the SAP environment. Application infrastructure objects can be discovered and instantiated; however, they do not have any direct relationship to computers. Only applications and software servers have relationships to computers. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about services that represent modules of an application, or services that are deployed on a server. Use this class and its subclasses to define the low level application services in your organization. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about low-level, built-in software used to start a computer's operating system without accessing programs from a disk. A subclass of BMC_SystemSoftware, BMC_BIOSElement can be used to represent specific operating system and BIOS (basic input/output system) software elements in your IT environment. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_BIOSElement.

Class that stores information about printed circuit boards, such as hosting boards or motherboards, that you can insert into a computer to give it added capabilities. It can include information about any package capable of carrying signals and providing a mounting point for physical components, such as chips or other cards. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Card class.

Class that stores information about the capabilities and management of CD-ROM drives. A CD-ROM drive is a device that reads information from a CD-ROM. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_CDROMDrive class.

Class that stores information about frames that serve as the structural support for a computer system's electronic components. It can include information about physical elements that enclose other elements and provide definable functionality, such as a desktop computer, a processing node, an uninterruptible power supply (UPS), disk or tape storage, or a combination of such elements. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Chassis class.
Specifies the cost incurred for providing a service.

Class that stores information about a collection of logical storage areas that hold and retain data. You model database storage CIs as an instance of the BMC_DataBaseStorage class (derived from the BMC_FileSystem class), and identify the instance by its Name and SystemName attributes. The BMC_DataBaseStorage class extends a file system CI and uses its inherited associations to represent the internal structure of the database. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_DatabaseStorage.

Class that stores information about disk partitions. A disk partition is a contiguous range of logical blocks (groups of records) that the operating system can identify by the partition's type and subtype fields. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_DiskPartition class.
Class that stores information about noncomputing equipment, such as vehicles and maintenance tools. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about systems that operating systems or programs use to organize and keep track of files and datasets. The file systems can be local (such as an instance of BMC_ComputerSystem or BMC_ApplicationSystem) or remotely mounted from a file server. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_FileSystem class.

CMDB Abstract Class stores the cost and price information associated to a service offering. This class is further specialized by the BMC_Cost and BMC_Price classes. BMC_Cost represents the cost incurred in providing a certain service and BMC_Price specifies how much a consumer is required to pay for the service.

Class that stores information about the capabilities and management of floppy drives. A floppy drive is a machine that reads data from and writes data to a disk. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about hardware components that are made up of other hardware components. Use this class to represent hardware components that are not represented by other CDM classes. For example, chassis and monitors are represented by the CDM classes BMC_Chassis and BMC_Monitor, but no BMC class represents RAID disk arrays. To relate instances of the BMC_HardwareSystemComponent class to an instance of this class, you can use the BMC_HostedSystemComponents class. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about groups of related IP protocol endpoints that can communicate with each other as members of a subnet. This class describes the characteristics of the subnet. Endpoint instances are related to an instance of this class by a BMC_InIPSubnet relationship. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_IPConnectivitySubnet class.
Class that stores information about networks or subnets that use the IPX protocol. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_IPXConnectivityNetwork class.

Class that stores information about keyboards attached to computer systems. A keyboard is a set of typewriter-like keys that enables you to enter data into a computer. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Keyboard class.

Class that is used to classify collections of configuration items (CIs) related to IP subnets in a local area network (LAN). The subnets are represented by instances of BMC_IPConnectivitySubnet. The instances are related by a BMC_IPSubnetsInCollection relationship. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about the organization of files residing on a computer system (BMC_ComputerSystem instance). Such files are directly managed by the computer system without the need for another computer to act as a file server. In a clustered file system, each file system is an instance of BMC_LocalFileSystem, weak to the cluster. To represent the cluster, use the BMC_Cluster class. To relate instances of BMC_LocalFileSystem to the cluster, you can use the BMC_HostedSystemComponents class. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_LocalFileSystem class.

Specifies a representation of a contiguous range of logical blocks that is identifiable by applications such as file systems by way of the Name field. For example on Windows, the Name attribute might specify the hard disk drive name. On UNIX, the attribute might contain the access path /dev/... . The File system application uses this attribute to identify the logical disk for accessing the media.This class is used to model virtual disks allocated to virtual machines.
Class that stores information about display screens attached to computer systems. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_DesktopMonitor class.

Class used to store information about interfaces that connect network drives to computer systems. Each instance of this class is related to the computer system by a BMC_HostedSystemComponents relationship. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_NetworkPort class.

Class that stores information about containers or collections of related software. As a subclass of BMC_Product, this class can be used to represent a package or suite of products. For example, you could represent Microsoft Office as an instance of BMC_Package, whereas Microsoft Word would be an instance of BMC_Product. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about fixes (service patches) for program defects. For example, IT adminstrators can use the ServicePackInEffect attribute to define a specific service pack that a given patch applies to, to ensure that the patch is not propagated to incorrect service pack versions. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about devices that you use to control the movement of a pointer to select items on a display screen. Pointing devices include a mouse, digitizing pad, track ball, and touch pad. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_PointingDevice class.

Class that stores information about commodities, such as software. Use this class to capture the installed, static aspects of a software product (such as Microsoft Word). You can also use this class to represent noncommercial products, such as software programs developed for in-house use only. To represent the installed version of an application, create a BMC_Product instance. To capture the deployed, run-time aspects of long-lived applications, use BMC_SoftwareServer, BMC_Application, or BMC_ApplicationInfrastructure, depending on the type. For example, Microsoft Word installed on your computer is a CI of BMC_Product; however, every running version of Microsoft Word is an instance of BMC_SoftwareServer. As another example, you would create a BMC_Product instance to represent the installed version of WebServer, and create several BMC_SoftwareServer instances to represent actual instances of WebServer, one listening on port 80, another on port 8000, and a third on port 8080. This class corresponds to the DMTF class CIM_Product.
Class that stores information about hardware rack components, which hold other hardware components within a system. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_Rack class.

Class that stores information about file systems that are not directly connected to a computer system. Instead, they are hosted by a computer acting as a file server. Use this class to represent file systems that a computer gains access to through a network-related service. For example, the file store for a network file system is typically NOT on a computer's locally controlled media, nor is it directly accessed through a device driver. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_RemoteFileSystem class.

Class that serves as a logical entity (with associated controls) provided by the host system to allocate and assign resources. A given ResourcePool may be used to allocate resources of a specific type. Hierarchies of ResourcePools may be created to provide administrative control over allocations. In cases where resources are subdivided, multiple resource pools may exist (for example, nodal boundaries in NUMA-like systems). In systems that support over-commitment, pools represent the reservable capacity, not an upper bound or limit on the maximum amount that can be allocated. Admission control during power-on may detect and prevent systems from powering due to resource exhaustion. For example, over-commitment on a ResourcePool with ResourceType=Memory would require that sufficient space be available in a backing store that might be managed through a storage ResourcePool.
Class that stores information about components, such as files, folders, or printers, that are shared by multiple computer systems or users. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
Specifies a contiguous range of logical blocks on a storage media, which supports storing and retrieving data, for example, an external hard disk

Specifies a raw storage extent that a virtual or physical machine can access, when it has a volume manager to manage the storage directly, from the host machine or from the network storage. For example in a Linux environment, one or more physical volumes (PVs) are created from a disk drive and logical volumes are created from these PVs.

Class that stores information about an entity managed by a BIOS (basic input/output system), an operating system, or other software that is available for use by application software, logical devices, or both. System resources are individually identified and allocated entities that are assignable, reservable, counted or tracked, releasable, resetable, and so on. Examples of software resources are message queues, shared memory segments (identified by a key value), and named pipes. Examples of hardware resources in an x86 environment are IRQs, DMA channels, and memory-mapped I/O. Another example is J2EE resources used by a J2EE server to provide the J2EE standard services required by the J2EE platform architecture. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_SystemResource class.

Abstract class that contains the information necessary to represent, configure, and manage the functionality provided by a device or software feature. A service is a general-purpose object to configure and manage the implementation of functionality. For example, IT administrators can use both the SystemClassId and SystemName attributes to specifically configure a service to only systems assigned a specific name and identification number. When the attribute is defined, it is automatically propagated to the related configuration item (CI). Note: a system service is different from a business service, which is considered a logical entity. By definition, abstract classes cannot hold any instances. You use them only in special cases to organize subclasses so that you have the flexibility to add a layer of organization without a database join. Therefore, you might use the only subclass, BMC_ApplicationService, to store information about configuring and managing software features and functionality for specific types of system services in your organization. This subclass contains an attribute in which you can record the fully qualified path to the service binary file that implements the service.

Specifies a label that can be associated to any CI. This label is used to categorize the CIs to create a logical grouping. For example, the administrator of a blueprint deployment can tag the resource set as public, private, secure, and highly secure. This will then be used by the placement engine in performing the deployment in appropriate network zones.

Class that stores information about the capabilities and management of tape drives. A tape drive is a device that reads data from and writes it to a tape. This class corresponds to the DMTF CIM_TapeDrive class.

Class that stores information about uninterruptible power supply (UPS) systems, which maintain power for your organization and its systems during power outages. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about software that enables a collection of virtual computer systems to run on a single physical computer system (for example, VMware). This class is used to capture the virtualization OS, such as operating systems that run virtual machines (including VMware images, Solaris zones, AIX logical partitions, HP-UX virtual partitions, and so forth). This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class, that stores information about collections of configuration items (CIs) related to IP subnets in a wide area network (WAN). The BMC_WAN class has no direct subclasses, but it includes several attributes that specify various properties of the WAN. For example, the WANType attribute defines the protocol used for the WAN as ATM, Frame Relay, Unknown, or Other. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
Class that stores information about a Mainframe Coupling Facility.This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.

Class that stores information about a storage subsystem.Each storage system can be either a direct access storage device (DASD) subsystem, for example, Disk or a Tape Subsystem (Tape) type. This class has no corresponding distributed management task force (DMTF) common infomation model (CIM) class.

BMC_LNsCollection.Class that represents groups of logical networks (LNs) that are, in turn, collections of endpoints. For example, you can use this class to group IPSubnets that are deployed across the same physical LAN or WAN. You can also use this class to model subsets of larger physical networks. For example, if you have ten computers connected to the same networking backbone, you could have five of the computers on the address range 192.168.0.x, and the other five computers on the address range 172.16.10.x. Although they are physically connected to the same backbone, the two groups of five computers are part of two separate logical networks. This class has no corresponding DMTF CIM class.
